lead_paragraph: Translators, now facing Taliban threats, said the United States promised to keep them safe. Congress is bickering over the program meant to be their deliverance.

byline.contributor: Mohammad Fahim Abed contributed reporting from Kabul, Afghanistan.

headline.print_headline: Broken Promises for Afghans Who Aided U.S.
headline.main: ‘They Will Kill Us’: Afghan Translators Plead for Delayed U.S. Visas

snippet: Translators, now facing Taliban threats, said the United States promised to keep them safe. Congress is bickering over the program meant to be their deliverance....
abstract: Republican infighting has thrown into question future of special visa program for translators and interpreters who helped American miltary during Afghanistan and Iraq wars; failure to renew program places interpreters in grave danger of reprisal by extremist groups, damages American credibility and deals harsh blow to approximately 12,000 Afghans whose immigration applications are in limbo.
